title: On Media
text:
Moderators step back and Harris seizes moment

Democratic presidential candidates former vice president Joe Biden, left, Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., and Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif., stand on stage for a photo op before the start of the the Democratic primary debate on June 27, 2019. | AP/Wilfredo Lee

Debate moderators allowed Democratic candidates the opportunity to confront each other last night, and Sen. Kamala Harris, for one, took advantage. Welcome to On Media.

"THE SENATOR TOOK THE LEAD, and so she created an exchange with him,” NBC News chairman Andrew Lack told POLITICO in the spin room following the debate.

Story Continued Below

Lack said the NBC team “expected that exchange” given Harris’s earlier criticism of Biden’s comments, but they “didn’t know how, when, precisely what the character of it would be.” And, he added, “it was a mystery to us what [Biden] was going to say.”

“I’m in a truck with 15 screens, and I’m looking at the two of them, and we’re directing shots, and the important piece for us just to give them a chance to speak to each other in the way that they did,” Lack said. “And it was quite compelling.”

More from my post-debate piece is here.

A box of popcorn sits next to reporters as they watch Democratic presidential candidate and U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) on a monitor inside the spin room during the first Democratic presidential primary debate on June 26, 2019 in Miami, Florida. | Drew Angerer/Getty Images

MORE THAN 15 MILLION VIEWERS watched Wednesday night’s debate across NBC, MSNBC, and Telemundo, an impressive number that came just shy of the record-setting first Democratic debate of the 2016 cycle. (The first Republican debate last time around drew a whopping 24 million.)

DNC chairman Tom Perez was clearly pleased with the ratings. When I asked him about 15 million tuning in, he responded that there were 24 million. (Indeed, NBC says 9 million watched via live stream.) Perez said the party's energy hasn't abated from the women's marches to the midterms to the 2020 primary. "People understand that democracy is not a spectator sport," he said.

The first night, which only included one top-polling candidate, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, has been expected to draw smaller ratings. Some campaigns were told that NBC’s decision on which group of 10 went first was to “maximize viewership.” We should find out this afternoon if night two comes out on top.

Former Maryland congressman John Delaney speaks to the media in the spin room following the first night of the Democratic presidential debate on June 26, 2019 in Miami, Florida. | Drew Angerer/Getty Images

IF CANDIDATES CALLED THE SHOTS: “I don’t think I got enough opportunities,” former Maryland Rep. John Delaney told me of his time on stage Wednesday night. “I think that was probably obvious by me trying to wedge in as much as I could.”

What would he do differently? “I’d have 10 questions and every candidate would have to answer them and they would rotate and you’d have 45 seconds,” Delaney said.

Washington governor Jay Inslee told me there should be “a debate dedicated to climate change” because a few questions in each of 12 debates isn't sufficient. “If we really want to understand how to mobilize the entire United States...we need a full debate,” he said.

Democratic presidential candidate, former Rep. Beto O’Rourke (D-TX) speaks to the media as he visits the outside of a detention center for migrant children on June 27, 2019 in Homestead, Florida. | Joe Raedle/Getty Images

HIGHLIGHTING HOMESTEAD: Over the past few days, at least a third of the Democratic field traveled 30 miles southwest to the Homestead detention center, "the largest shelter for unaccompanied migrant minors in the whole country,” writes The Daily Beast’s Gideon Resnick. “They would come and cause a melee of sweaty cameramen.”
description: Your guide to the media circus
